column4: anyone knows if ubuntu plays well with nvidia video cards that are rated for PCI Express 2.0 slot but are used in PCI Express x16 slot?
that is related to the motherboard, not to ubuntu

i know the hardware works but will ubuntu have any issues though, that is what I am asking, I can stick a PCI Express 2.0 video card in a PCI Express x16 slot, no issue there but will the OS have any issues???
why should the os have an issue with that? if the hardware and connection is ok, ubunu does not care about it
its more important that the drivers support the card
you must be new at this then, people have had issues with something as basic as memory
memory-problems are hardware/motherboard problems, not ubuntu problems
drivers are not implemented in hardware
i mean the nvidia-linux-driver must support the card
if the card is to new maybe there is no linux-driver for it
ok before I decide which one to buy I will look up the list for supported hardward,t hanks
yes, that is a good idea, the rest (pci x16, pci 2.0) is not part of ubuntu but of your board/the card
jaunty is working fine
not on my desktop and on my laptop karmic is a whole lot better than jaunty, karmic doesnt crash, jaunty crashed my desktop all the time and it crashed my laptop every now and then
but you are not all jaunty-users
so please dont tell anyone jaunty is not working
rm removes it permanetly (if there are no hardlinks anymore)
true but using forensic utilities you may still be able to look at the data, i thought rm mainly sets the disk space as writable again, not securely erase, as in wipe or shred
rm is not deleting
m is only removing the hard-link node
unlink is removing the file if i am correct which is called after hardlinks =0
